name: clinker production | municipal solid waste | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/22070/documentation

Clinker - Activity starts with reception of raw material at factory gate and its internal transportation for prehomogenisation and raw meal grinding where different raw materials are mixed to obtain the chemical composition required for cement. The homogenized raw meal then fed to preheater tower to preheat the feed before entering to precalciner & kiln. A pre-heater is a series of vertical cyclones through which the raw meal is passed, coming into contact with swirling hot gases moving in the opposite direction. Precalcination takes place in precalciner where decomposition of limestone to lime take place. The required reactions, which also need heat energy inputs, are stimulated at two points in the manufacturing process: within the “precalciner”, a combustion chamber at the bottom of the pre-heater above the kiln, and within the kiln itself. The precalcined meal then enters the kiln, where intense heat – up to 1450°C – causes chemical and physical reactions that partially melt the meal into “clinker”, an intermediate product in cement manufacturing that becomes the main substance in cement and is commonly traded. From the kiln, the hot clinker falls onto a grate cooler where it is cooled by incoming combustion air, thereby minimising energy loss from the system. Depending on the requirement clinker can be stored in the silo to use for making different type of cement or transported to different location.  Total clinker production in india during the year of 2014-15 is approximately 190 million tonnes. Clinker is basic raw material for production of cement. 

From the reception of traditional and alternative fuels and raw materials at the factory gate. 

This activity ends with the cooling of the produced clinker. It includes the whole manufacturing process to produce clinker , internal processes (transport, etc.) and for the infrastructure only the rotary kiln (material consumption) is taken into account. No administration is included. Waste (as secondary fuel and raw material) enter the system without environmental burdens from upstream processes.

processDocumentation.timeDescription: For this activity time period of 2014 to 2017 has been considered . As during this period Indian cement industry has done significant works in improving energy efficiency by installing energy efficient equipment, process optimization, equipment retrofit etc.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data represents for all geographical locations where cement has been manufactured in India.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: For this activity latest available technologies were considered like Vertical roller mill, energy efficient fans, use of efficienct burner and cooler etc.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Data represents for 60% of the total installed cement capacity in India in the year of 2014-15.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: For this activity sample questionnaire has been prepared and circulated to all cement manufacturing units in India. Here we have selected clusterwise approch for collecting the data. Due to clusterwise approch variation in quality of raw material , different technologies etc. has taken care. After receiving the data from plants same has been analysed for any discripancies. Extreme minimum and maximum values reported by plants were removed. Final numbers were checked with cement industry expert. We have received data from more than 25 cement plants in India.

exchanges.description: Weighted average of more than 25 cement producer in india during the year 2014-15. In Indian cement plants various types of alternative fuels were used as replacement of primary fuel such as coal. Differant types of alterntive fuels are used in India are Rice husk, Tyre, Biomass, Muncipal Solid Waste, Rubber, Paint, Wood Dust, Saw Dust, ETP Sludge, Pharmaceutical Waste etc, The uses of alternate fuel in India is very low in comparison with what can be observed in other countries. The global average secondary fuel use in cement industry is near about 4%. In some countries the average use is as high as more than 30%, whereas in India the average is below 1%.
